awd_titl_txt: Determining Degrees of Freedom in Nonlinear Complex Systems: Deterministic and Stochastic Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Almost every aspect of our physical world is described through a nonlinear complex system, from the functioning of our brains to climatic changes. In order to extract concrete information from such systems, suitable mathematical models must be designed so as to capture the most relevant cross-scale interactions and degrees of freedom. In this project the PI will investigate the efficiency of methods for exploring complex system models under two main perspectives. First, through techniques of statistical inference of physical quantities based on observational data. Several applications fit within this scope, for example determining the background fluid velocity field from measurements of the concentration of a diluted passive scalar, such as dye. A second application is the analysis of the long-time behavior of computable regularizations of certain hydrodynamics models. More specifically, geophysical models describing the motion of fluids over a rough surface and used to represent large-scale processes in the atmosphere and ocean. A rigorous analysis of such fundamental questions encompasses a wide range of mathematical tools. As such, the techniques built here may allow for the development of efficient numerical schemes in numerous applications, as well as the advancement of the associated mathematical theory. In addition, this project presents an educational component by including support for the mentoring of one graduate student, as well as undergraduate research co-op support for one undergraduate student.

A rigorous and complete description of complex systems requires an analysis at an infinite-dimensional level. In this project the PI will this infinite-dimensional approach to analyze the efficiency of Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms, as used in the Bayesian approach to inverse problems. Of particular importance are MCMC algorithms that are well-defined in infinite dimensions, a property that allows corresponding finite-dimensional approximations to beat the curse of dimensionality. This project will tackle several open questions in this field, such as the derivation of mixing rates for some infinite-dimensional MCMC methods and their corresponding finite-dimensional approximations. The techniques to be used here rely crucially on Foias-Prodi type estimates and the existence of a finite number of determining degrees of freedom for certain dissipative evolution equations. Furthermore, this project includes the study of the long-time behavior of certain hydrodynamic models, such as the weakly damped 2D Euler equations subject to a mild regularization. In particular, this will first be addressed through the concept of determining forms, structures encoding the long-time dynamics of the system based on knowledge on the trajectories of only a finite number of degrees of freedom. Later, the system will be analyzed under the action of a stochastic forcing term. Here, an interesting question consists in establishing the convergence of invariant measures as the regularization parameter vanishes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project contributed to the rigorous understanding of various crucial aspects of the evolution of nonlinear complex systems, from both statistical and deterministic perspectives. This included the analysis of existing as well as derivation of novel statistical sampling algorithms for estimating unknown parameters in a given model from sparse and noisy data; the derivation of rates of convergence towards statistically steady states; the study of the probabilistic evolution of uncertainties in initial states for deterministic systems; and the investigation of correctness of certain models by analyzing the possible existence of solutions that blowup in finite time, in a certain sense. The novel developments in these directions produced general and rigorous results which play a crucial role in determining accurate forecasts of the evolution of many complex physical systems. As such, these results are applicable to a wide range of physical situations arising in several areas such as Engineering, Geophysics, Climatology, Epidemiology, Machine Learning, etc. 

More specifically, the results obtained in this project can be subdivided into four main topics, described as follows. Firstly, the project yielded results concerning Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithms and their applications to solving Bayesian inverse PDE problems. This included the derivation of rates of convergence of an exact version of the Hamiltonian Monte Carlo algorithm, and the application to the inverse problem of recovering a background fluid flow from sparse and noisy observations of the concentration of a passive solute (e.g. dye, or a pollutant) advected by the flow. It also produced a general framework encompassing a broad class of reversible Metropolis-Hastings type algorithms, including several popular existing ones, while also allowing for the derivation of new algorithms, with either single or multiple proposals at each iteration. Additionally, this general framework served as the basis for the study of certain surrogate trajectory-type algorithms, which introduce an approximation in the proposal generation step that allows for much lower computational costs, while maintaining unbiasedness. 

Secondly, general results were developed concerning the long-time behavior and ergodicity of stochastically forced systems, yielding exponential rates of convergence towards statistical equilibrium (mixing rates) and long-time accuracy of corresponding numerical approximations. These were applied in the context of fluid flows modeled by the Navier-Stokes equations in various scenarios. Next, another comprehensive framework was developed for the study of the probabilistic evolution of uncertainties in initial states of deterministic systems, via the concept of associated statistical solutions. In particular, the framework provides a set of conditions under which a sequence of statistical solutions of approximating schemes of a given model is guaranteed to converge to a statistical solution of the latter. Here, applications were given in the context of the inviscid limit of viscous fluid flows modeled by the Navier-Stokes equations, with the limiting flow thus modeled by the Euler equations, and also for a certain numerical approximation of the Navier-Stokes equations. Finally, this project included the description and analysis of possible scenarios where solutions to a particular class of hydrodynamic models may develop a blowup in finite time, characterizing an unphysical behavior. Specifically, this was done for the generalized surface quasi-geostrophic equation, a model associated with the evolution of surface temperature or buoyancy in certain large-scale atmospheric or oceanic flows. 

This project produced one book chapter, five publications in well regarded journals, and one preprint. In addition, the results obtained here laid the groundwork for the development of several other research projects to be pursued in the near future, which will lead to many further publications. This project also included the mentoring of two undergraduate students as part of summer research co-ops, and three graduate students (one Master and two Ph.D.’s). The training and guidance provided by this mentorship gave these students the opportunity to present their research results in conferences, write articles, or to successfully move on to promising next steps in their careers.
